bibl.title: The Medical and Surgical History of the War of the Rebellion. (1861–65.)
bibl.editor: Surgeon General Joseph K. Barnes, United States Army

keywords.term: on special wounds and injuries of the head
wounds and injuries of the head
conoidal ball caused wound of scalp on back of head
died from exhaustion following gunshot wound

revisionDesc.change: additional proofing of transcription and encoding, edited and added keyword terms
additional proofing of transcription and encoding
case text extracted and transformed from larger file
initial checking of OCR text against PDF; encoded

body.p: CASE.—Private David J. Huganer, Co. K, 6th New York Heavy Artillery, aged 42 years, was wounded, at Cold Harbor, Virginia, May 30th, 1864, by a conoidal ball, which caused a wound of the scalp on the back of the head. He was admitted to the hospital of the Third Division, Fifth Corps; on June 3d, sent to the Stanton Hospital, Washington, D. C., and, on June 21st, transferred to the McDougall Hospital, New York, where he died, on October 5th, 1864, from "exhaustion following gunshot wound." Assistant Surgeon S. H. Orton, U. S. A., reported the case.
